birds.name: European Starling
birds.overview: The European Starling was brought to the US by Shakespeare enthusiasts who wanted America to have all the birds that Shakespeare ever mentioned. They are now one of the most abundant birds in North America with a population of approximately 200 million.
birds.eggs: Greenish to bluish white, incubation period about 12 days.

birds.name: American Robin
birds.overview: Robins are a very popular North American bird. Though they are familiar town and city birds, American Robins are at home in wilder areas, too, including mountain forests and Alaskan wilderness.
birds.eggs: Pale blue (or Robin's egg blue), incubation period 12-14 days.

birds.name: Barn Swallow
birds.overview: Barn swallows make cup-shaped mud nests, almost exclusively in barns or other human-made structures, hence their name. As well as being in the Northeast, the species is common across Europe and Asia, wintering to southern Africa and South America.
birds.eggs: White spotted with brown, incubation period 13-17 days.

birds.name: Acorn Woodpecker
birds.overview: Acorn woodpeckers live in large groups in Western oak woodlands. They store thousands of acorns by pecking them into specially made holes in trees.
birds.eggs: White eggs, incubation period 11-14 days.

birds.name: American Crow
birds.overview: Crows are extremely common in farmlands, towns and cities. They are known to be sociable and gather in roosts on cold winter nights. They are one of the most intelligent birds.
birds.eggs: Blue-green to gray-green dotted with brown and gray, incubation period 18 days.

birds.name: American Goldfinch
birds.overview: The finch is the state bird of New Jersey, Iowa and Washington. In winter, finches congregate in weedy fields. In the spring, males are a brilliant yellow and shiny black with a bit of white.
birds.eggs: Pale bluish white, occasionally with light brown spots, incubation period 12-14 days.

birds.name: House Sparrow
birds.overview: House sparrows are one of the most popular songbirds in the world today. It thrives in the city and enjoys being around humans.
birds.eggs: Whitish to greenish white, with brown and gray dots, incubation period 10-14 days.

birds.name: Brown-headed Cowbird
birds.overview: Cowbirds have followed herds of cattle for centuries from coast to coast. Cowbirds lay their eggs in other birds' nests, causing some species to become endangered.
birds.eggs: Whitish with brown and gray spots. Female can lay up to 40 eggs in a season, removing eggs from host nest and laying one of her own.

birds.name: Buff-collared Nightjar
birds.overview: The Nightjar is one of the only nocturnal birds that isn't an owl.
birds.eggs: Pale buff, heavily marked with spots of lilac and brown, incubating period 3 weeks. These birds do not make a nest - they lay their eggs on dead leaves or soil.

birds.name: Black-capped chickadee
birds.overview: These chickadees are a very popular North American bird. They are known for taking sunflower seeds one at a time from bird feeders and stuffing them under tree bark.
birds.eggs: White, with fine dots of reddish brown, incubation period 12-13 days.

birds.name: Barn Owl
birds.overview: The barn owl preys chiefly on mice and rats and roosts in barns and other structures. It is often heard at night as it flies over farmland and marshes.
birds.eggs: Whitish, incubation period 29-34 days.

birds.name: Common Grackle
birds.overview: Common Grackles often nest in small colonies, and several males may perch in adjacent treetops.
birds.eggs: Pale blue, blotched with brown, incubation period 12-14 days.

birds.name: Common Nighthawk
birds.habitat: Open country, some cities and towns
birds.overview: The Nighthawk hunts both by day and night, catching flying insects in the air. Nighhawks nest on flat gravel roofs.
birds.eggs: Whitish to pale gray, heavily spotted with brown, incubation period about 19 days.

birds.name: Blue Jay
birds.habitat: Oak and pine woods, suburban gardens, towns and cities
birds.overview: Blue Jays are one of the most popular and most easily recognizable birds. Their birdsong is beautiful, but they take advantage of other birds. They often steal eggs from other nests and will eat almost anything.
birds.eggs: Greenish, sometimes pale blue, spotted with brown and gray, incubation period 16-18 days.

birds.name: House Finch
birds.overview: House Finches are common across North America. They are originally from the Southwest and are only recent arrivals in the East.
birds.eggs: Pale blue with black and lavender dots, incubation period 13-14 days.

birds.name: Song Sparrow
birds.overview: Song sparrows are familiar birds in the Northeast. It often hides in bushes, only seen flying to another inconspicuous area.
birds.eggs: Pale greenish white, heavily spotted with reddish brown, incubation period about 12-14 days.

birds.name: Red-winged Blackbird
birds.habitat: Breeds in marshes, brushy swamps, hayfields.
birds.overview: The red-winged blackbird is another popular bird, common across all of North America. They are boldly colored and are often seen on marshlands atop cattails.
birds.eggs: Pale blue-green, with markings of black, brown, purple. Incubation period is 10-12 days.

birds.name: House Wren
birds.overview: The House Wren was named for its tendency to nest in human homes and birdhouses. They are active and inquisitive.
birds.eggs: White, heavily dotted with reddish brown. Incubation period bout 12-15 days.

birds.name: Mourning Dove
birds.habitat: Farms, towns, open woods, roadsides, grasslands.
birds.overview: The cooing of the mourning dove is a familiar sound for many. This is one of North America's most common birds, abundant in the country and on road sides.
birds.eggs: White, incubation period about 14 days.

birds.name: Rock Pigeon
birds.habitat: Cities, farms, bridges. Most common in North American around cities.
birds.overview: These pigeons make themselves at home in big cities. It is also known as the Common City Pigeon. It lives in wild or semi-wild condition in cities all over the world.
birds.eggs: White, incubation period about 14 days.

birds.name: Northern Cardinal
birds.habitat: Woodland edges, thickets, suburban gardens, towns.
birds.overview: One of our most popular birds, the Cardinal is the official state bird of no fewer than seven eastern states.
birds.eggs: Whitish to pale bluish or greenish white, marked with brown, purple, and gray. Incubation period about 12-13 days.

birds.name: Tufted Titmouse
birds.overview: This bird is common all year in eastern forests. When a titmouse finds a large seed, you will ll see it carry the prize to a perch and crack it with sharp whacks of its stout bill.
birds.eggs: White, finely dotted with brown, reddish, or purple. Incubation period about 12-14 days.

birds.name: Red-bellied Woodpecker
birds.overview: This particular woodpecker is more common in the southeast. The woodpecker has adjusted to life in suburbs and city parks.
birds.eggs: White. Incubation period about 12-14 days.

birds.name: Eastern Bluebird
birds.habitat: Open country with scattered trees; farms, roadsides.
birds.overview: This is the most popular of all types of bluebirds. It is mostly found on the east coast but its' total range extends south to Nicaragua.
birds.eggs: Pale blue, sometimes white. Incubation period about 13-16 days.

birds.name: Ruby-throated Hummingbird
birds.overview: The Ruby-throated hummingbird is the only hummingbird close to the east coast. Hummingbirds can beat their wings more than 50 times per second.
birds.eggs: White. Incubation period about 11-16 days.
